title: Preseli Hills Walk Route

images.title: Gordon Hatton / On the 'Golden Road' across Mynydd Preseli, via Wikimedia Commons
images.caption: On the 'Golden Road' across Mynydd Preseli, following an ancient trackway along the Preseli ridge in Pembrokeshire.

images.title: Dylan Moore / Meadows at the foot of the Preseli, via Wikimedia Commons
images.caption: Meadows at the foot of the Preseli. On the right-centre horizon is Foel Cwmcerwyn, the highest point (536 m) in the Preseli hills.

images.title: Garth Newton / The northern slopes of the Preseli Hills, via Wikimedia Commons
images.caption: The view from the northern slopes of the Preseli Hills near Cilgwyn towards the Afon Nyfer which feeds into Newport Bay.

images.title: Deborah Tilley / Carnau Lladron in the Preseli Hills, via Wikimedia Commons
images.caption: Carnau Lladron. An area becoming popular with hanglider enthusiasts.

images.title: Deborah Tilley / Preseli Hills, via Wikimedia Commons
images.caption: High moorland on the Preselis. Home to grazing sheep and hardy mountain ponies. There is even mention of the occasional 'big cat'! Yet to be confirmed! Carn Ingli is seen to the right of the picture. It straddles the borough of Newport and the Cwm Gwaun, a steep sided valley formed by glacial meltwaters. On the summit there's several fascinating ancient sites dating from the Iron Age and the Bronze Age.

images.title: Andrew Howey / Carn Siân, Preseli Mountains, via Wikimedia Commons
images.caption: Carn Siân, A path marking stone on the northern slopes of Carn Siân in the Preseli Mountains, Pembrokeshire. The view is westwards along the ridge track to Foel Feddau, with Foel Cwmcerwyn obscured by cloud to the left. The peak of Foel Eryr (468m) is on the horizon.

images.title: Andrew Howey / The ancient hill fort of Foeldrygarn, Preseli Mountains, via Wikimedia Commons
images.caption: The ancient hill fort of Foeldrygarn, Preseli Mountains. The peak of Foeldrygarn (363m) in the Preseli Mountains is the site of an ancient hill fort. The view from the trig point shows part of one of the defensive walls.

images.title: Dylan Moore / Preseli sheepwalk, via Wikimedia Commons
images.caption: Preseli sheepwalk. In the distance to the left is Foel Eryr, and to the right is Foel Cwmcerwyn, the highest point in the Preseli Hills. The ancient boundary bank between Nevern (left) and Morvil (right) parishes stretches away in the right of the picture.

description: This splendid walking trail runs right along the spine of the Preseli Hills giving wonderful views of the area. On a clear day you can see Cardigan Bay, Snowdonia and even Ireland. You will also pass two quarries which are believed to have provided the stones for Stonehenge. The road is thought to date back to Neolithic times. It's a 7 mile linear route but you could turn it into a circular walk by following the country lane at the end of the route south east towards Rosebush and then turning north through the Pantmaenog Forest to return to the start point. The walk starts at the Bwlch Gwynt car park on the B4329 and heads east following the trail past the northern end of the Pantmeanog Forest. Here you have the option to take a short detour south to Foel Cwmcerwyn , the highest point in the Presili Hills. You continue east to the Bronze Age burial cairn at Foel Feddau and then on to the rocky tor Carn Bica, which overlooks Bedd Arthur, a Neolithic ring of stones in the shape of an eye. The final section takes you past the Foel Drygarn Iron Age fortress before finishing near Crymych. On the route you can look out for wildlife such as buzzard, red kite and wild ponies on the grassland.
